name: Grotto Falls
description: A waterfall located along the Trillium Gap Trail that you can walk behind. It creates a soft flowing beauty and a magical photography opportunity.
tips: Shoot on a cloudy day to capture soft, silky water without harsh highlights
Walk behind the waterfall for a unique perspective
The hike is 2.6 miles round trip

name: The Sinks Waterfall
description: A popular waterfall on the park's western side that is easily accessible due to its proximity to a major road.
tips: Use a circular polarizer to manage reflections in water shots
Overcast conditions act as a soft box for long exposures of water features
Requires less hiking than other water features in the park

name: Lake McDonald
description: A beautiful lake where you can drive right up to primo photography spots without a long hike. It features countless little coves and a dock in Apgar that provide excellent reflections and sunset views.
tips: Set up your camera at the Lake McDonald dock in Apgar
Look for countless little coves along the shore to find a peaceful, unique vantage point
The lake is known for excellent mountain reflections no matter the weather

name: Kuwohi Mountain
description: One of the premier overlooks in the park for capturing sunrises and sunsets, offering expansive views of multiple ridgelines stacked behind one another.
tips: Use a telephoto lens (e.g., 185mm) to compress the landscape.
Pick out a ridgeline in the foreground and stack the rest behind it to create depth.
Telephoto lenses make the ridges seem closer together than they actually are.

name: Newfound Gap Overlook
description: Located on the border of North Carolina and Tennessee, this location faces East and offers great views of the mountains.
tips: Face east for the best sunrise photography opportunities
Check out the spot where you can stand in two states at once

name: Primitive Baptist Church (Cades Cove)
description: A historic 19th-century church located in the Cades Cove valley, serving as a prominent historical display.
tips: The 11-mile one-way loop can have heavy traffic that stops frequently
Overcast skies provide soft lighting for historical buildings and foliage details
Use wide-angle lenses for architecture and zooms for isolating details

name: The Grinnell Glacier Trail
description: A trail with a high 'wow factor' where views get more spectacular with every step. The trail leaves the trees early, offering wide-open vistas and close-ups of the glacier and surrounding walls.
tips: Capture hikers in your frame to provide perspective on the massive scale of the landscape
Keep an eye out for mountain goats that often pose along the trail
The Garden Wall above the glacier looks particularly striking in evening light

name: John Oliver Cabin
description: A historic log cabin located in Cades Cove, known for a beautiful flowering dogwood tree positioned directly behind the structure.
tips: Time your visit in spring when dogwoods are flowering but before they get too green.
Compose the shot to show two sides of the house.
Ensure morning light is hitting one of the visible sides.
Keep the camera level to prevent the cabin sides from appearing tilted.

name: Morton’s Gap Overlook
description: Widely considered one of the top sunset locations within Great Smoky Mountains National Park.
tips: This is a premier location for capturing the sunset over the mountain ridges

name: Clingmans Dome
description: The highest peak in the park, offering high-altitude vistas, rising mist from Lake Fontana, and clear night skies.
tips: Arrive well before dawn to secure a spot as it attracts crowds
Bring a solid tripod for landscape or Milky Way shots
Dress in layers as temperatures can be 10-20 degrees cooler than lower elevations
Check for road closures (US 441) due to high winds or fog

name: Logan Pass
description: The high point of Going-to-the-Sun Road offering incredible views of Glacier in all its glory, including wildflower meadows and frequent wildlife sightings.
tips: Bring a good long-distance camera lens for wildlife like mountain goats, big horn rams, and grizzlies
Try to catch the blooming Glacier Lilies during the spring
Take the short walk from the visitor center to Hidden Lake Overlook for a great landscape perspective

name: Tom Branch Falls
description: An easily accessible and photogenic waterfall where the surrounding spring vegetation often exhibits a vibrant green glow.
tips: In spring, focus on capturing the glowing greens of the foliage.
Consider shooting through the trees to add a layered, framed perspective to the waterfall.

name: Parking at Mp14.4 Overlook
description: An unlabeled pullout just past Morton's Gap Overlook that faces west, offering spectacular mountain views framed by trees.
tips: Use the surrounding trees to frame the Appalachian mountains in the distance
Because it faces west, the sunset colors here are expected to be spectacular

name: Oconaluftee Visitor Center
description: An area near Cherokee, NC, known for wildlife sightings, particularly elk herds crossing the highway.
tips: Use a telephoto lens to capture wildlife from a safe distance
Maintain the park-mandated 50-yard limit from bears and elk
Be prepared for sudden opportunities as elk move across the major park highway

name: Elizabeth Lake
description: One of the most photogenic lakes in the park, located in the backcountry. It is highly valued by photographers for its serenity and the dramatic evening light on the water.
tips: Carry a tripod on your backpacking trip to capture Milky Way and night photography
Look for the resident pair of swans that call the lake home
Evening light is perfect for postcard-worthy sunset shots

name: Cades Cove Gravel Road
description: A specific gravel road section that provides excellent color contrast when the morning sun hits the trees.
tips: Requires a clear eastern horizon or a crack in the clouds.
Look for the moment when golden sunlight catches the trees while the gravel road remains in shadow.
This contrast creates a compelling blue-and-gold color palette.

name: Oconaluftee Valley Overlook
description: A magnificent overlook at parking area #4 along Newfound Gap Road, famous for its sunrise views over the valley.
tips: Arrive early to watch the sun rise over the valley
This view is so iconic it is featured in the Sugarlands Visitor Center

name: Cable Grist Mill
description: A historic mill built in 1868 featuring an overshot wheel and elaborate water diversions.
tips: Located at the far end of the Cades Cove loop road
Plan for a full day if stopping at historical sites along the 11-mile loop
Neutral density filters are useful for capturing motion in the water-powered wheel

name: Granite Park Chalet
description: A historic chalet built over 100 years ago that provides a picturesque setting for backcountry photography, offering views of the Garden Wall and surrounding peaks.
tips: Hike an additional 5 miles round trip to Swiftcurrent Lookout for the highest fire lookout views in the park
Visit the Grinnell Glacier Overlook via a 3-mile spur trail to look down on the glacier from the Garden Wall
Rain or shine, the chalet area provides dramatic weather-based photography opportunities like rainbows

name: Sunset Pullout (Below Kuwohi)
description: A pullout located further down the mountain from Kuwohi that provides beautiful valley views during sunset, even without a direct view of the sun disk.
tips: Ideal when there is dust or haze in the air, which creates a warm glow between ridges.
Focus on the light filling the valley floor rather than the sky.

name: Trillium Gap Trail
description: A beautiful trail that leads to Grotto Falls and eventually Mt. Le Conte, known for its misty atmosphere.
tips: Shoot in the early morning to capture beautiful misty fog
Arrive early as parking is extremely limited on the one-way Roaring Fork Motor Nature Trail

name: Foothills Parkway
description: A scenic drive along the western edge of the park offering views of Mount LeConte and Clingmans Dome.
tips: Provides a well-maintained, less congested alternative for panoramic vistas
Excellent for capturing fall colors through forested stretches
Use a telephoto lens to isolate the distant high peaks

name: Clingman’s Dome Parking Lot
description: The highest point in the park offers spectacular sunset views directly from the parking area.
tips: Look for the blue and purple hues that emanate from the mountains as the sun goes down
The view here is often just as good for photography as the tower itself

name: Deep Creek
description: An area near Bryson City featuring multiple waterfalls and access to whitewater streams.
tips: Requires a significant commitment of 'shoe leather' and hiking energy
Bring rain gear and camera protection for damp conditions near falls
Check local maps as cell service is non-existent in this area

name: Laurel Falls
description: A popular 80-foot cascading waterfall reachable via a paved but steep 2.6-mile round trip hike.
tips: Bring a wide angle lens because the footbridge crosses directly over the falls
Avoid midday shooting to prevent harsh lighting on the water

name: Blue Ridge Parkway
description: A scenic parkway intersecting the park near Oconaluftee that offers high-elevation hiking and panoramic overlooks.
tips: Accessed via the Cherokee entrance to the park
Use graduated density filters for high-contrast sunrise and sunset shots at overlooks
Keep a paper map handy as GPS can be unreliable in the mountains

name: Clingman’s Dome Observation Tower
description: A steep half-mile hike leads to a tower with a 360-degree view of the Smokies.
tips: Utilize the 360-degree view to shoot either sunrise or sunset
Be aware that high elevations often bring heavy cloud cover
Note that access road is closed in winter
